Escape From Tarkov Dev Trolls Players By Making Its Impossible Ending Even More Brutal

After player feedback said that the ending was too ruthless, developer Battlestate Games made it even more so

Escape From Tarkov

After a long, eight-year wait, players can finally escape from Tarkov in Escape from Tarkov. However, reaching the new end-game location, Terminal, is no easy feat, and neither is battling your way through to its conclusion. And now, following complaints from some in the Escape from Tarkov community who found escaping too difficult, developer Battlestate Games has decided to make things even harder.

As part of the long-awaited 1.0.0.2 update on December 1st of last year, Battlestate Games added four unique endings to Escape from Tarkovâ€™s gruelling 200-ish hour-long campaign. Battling through the chaotic wave of AI-controlled enemies is no simple task, especially since youâ€™ve just been stripped of all your gear, but things become all the more punishing once you reach Terminalâ€™s final hurdle. And according to PCGamesN, after some players said they found it too challenging, the devs decided that it actually still sounded a bit too easy.

If youâ€™ve yet to complete Terminal for yourself, be warned that weâ€™re about to get into heavy spoiler territory here.

When Escape from Tarkovâ€™s full release update dropped, it added a brutal decision that players had to make: a boat had to be taken to reach the titular escape, but it only fit three. The gameâ€™s standard player formation is squads of five. Thus, two people had to stay behind, becoming engulfed in a nuclear blast while others sail away to safety (and earning themselves one of Escape from Tarkovâ€™s â€œbadâ€ endings).

Naturally, considering all the work it takes to get to that point, a sizable chunk of the community complained online. This included Escape from Tarkov streamer Velion, who wrote, â€œI would really like to see this changed where everyone can escape together. Imagine being able to go into terminal and meeting 2 other players who you work together on a hard map and you survive and make it out.â€ Directing his feedback squarely at Battlestate Games, he tagged studio head Nikita Buyanov in his Twitter post.

Buyanov immediately replied by simply stating â€œits changed already,â€ which would reasonably lead you to assume that leaving Tarkov with all your buddies is now an option.

Turns out that Buyanov considers himself a comedian, as he actually meant that things have â€œchangedâ€ for the worse. As other players online have already pointed out, the number of players who can now escape at the end of Terminal has been whittled down to one.

Of course, you could just play through Terminal by yourself and not have to bother with the hassle of deciding which of you gets to live once it ends, but that feels like it defeats the point. Escape from Tarkov has always been a game about forging bonds and making friends, and watching them all get consumed by a nuclear blast while you sail off into the sunset, Titanic-style, just seems fitting.

item.title: Logan Paulâ€™s Pitch For A PokÃ©mon Game Is Nostalgia Brain Poison
item.content:encoded:
I donâ€™t pay much attention to Logan Paul, the content creator turned wrestler with side hustles that involve turning PokÃ©mon cards into heartless cash grabs and a failed NFT game. But the social media persona entered my field of view last night after making a now viral post pitching his idea for a new PokÃ©mon game. Well, â€œnewâ€ is a stretch, considering what heâ€™s asking for is essentially another fucking remake of the original PokÃ©mon Red and Blue games. But having been in the seriesâ€™ vicinity for almost 30 years, I know that this is the type of artless pitch lapsed and casual PokÃ©mon fans would happily gobble down like Moomoo Milk.

Pushing aside with all our might that this reads like a pitch to Game Freak that was probably written by ChatGPT (â€œnostalgic equityâ€ is a phrase no human has ever said), letâ€™s look at what Paul is actually asking for.

Idea for The PokÃ©mon Company:

I think there is a MASSIVE opportunity to capitalize on the decades of nostalgic equity that fans have with the franchise

The same frenzy that originally propelled PokÃ©mon into mainstream culture lives within millions of adults that yearn for theâ€¦

â€” Logan Paul (@LoganPaul) January 5, 2026

He says that The PokÃ©mon Company has a â€œmassive opportunityâ€ to bank on nostalgia, as if Pikachu and friends have ever not taken the opportunity to shove the original Kanto starters into something over the past 30 years. He also mentions how, every few years, heâ€™ll boot up the original games on a Game Boy to find â€œjust as much joyâ€ playing back through them as he had as a child. 

He then admits he doesnâ€™t have â€œmuch of a connectionâ€ to newer PokÃ©mon, which is where he begins to give the game away. He does like Annihilape and Baxcalibur, suggesting heâ€™s not completely out of the loop. But since he doesnâ€™t really seem to care about anything PokÃ©mon has done in the last 27 years, he argues it would be cool for Game Freak to create â€œremasteredâ€ versions of the Generation I Game Boy games, with â€œadaptive NPCs that evolve alongside the player.â€

He says they could even use modern technology to let players connect to the internet for trading and battling, something PokÃ©mon has literally been doing for 20 years, ever since Diamond and Pearl on the DS. He goes on:

This will do three things

1.) Give older fans a chance to relive their childhood thus awakening a massive, dormant demographic 

2.) Give newer, younger fans a taste of what originally made the franchise so special

3.) Bridge the gap for older fans who donâ€™t connect with newer PokÃ©mon in a way thatâ€™s familiar to them

If we believe that video game cycles are like a pendulum, the near-future of gaming may birth a desire for more simplified, block-based aesthetics. We already see it happening with games like Minecraft & Roblox. As technology continues to advance at an alarmingly rapid pace, I personally believe the future will lean towards â€œretroâ€

This LinkedIn-ass post tries to intellectualize what is obvious nostalgia-pining as some kind of market inevitability; that it would just be good business sense for PokÃ©mon to go back to Kanto for the people who only played those original games decades ago, outgrew them, and now think the problem is that the all-ages franchise has fallen â€œbehind the times.â€ Also, crucially, Game Freak already remade those original games twice with FireRed/LeafGreen and the Letâ€™s Go games on Switch, the latter of which are only seven years old.

Yes, the original Red and Blue are still the best-selling games in the franchise, and maybe some people are too young to realize that the level of PokÃ©mania back then was far beyond the still massive success PokÃ©mon enjoys right now. To insinuate that PokÃ©mon is in danger of getting away from its base of â€˜90s kids, though, is like saying the sun isnâ€™t shining because youâ€™re inside and canâ€™t feel its warmth. But this is the sentiment of a lot of retired PokÃ©mon trainers who stopped playing in elementary school and mistake their own lack of interest for the series no longer having the sauce.

Itâ€™s the same mentality that makes people mad that Scarlet and Violet have â€œregular animalsâ€ in them like Flamigo when Red and Blue had Seel, or who didnâ€™t like that Gen V and VI had PokÃ©mon made of â€œobjectsâ€ when Grimer and Voltorb were literal sludge and a living PokÃ© Ball. PokÃ©mon made me feel something specific as a child, and now that Iâ€™m an adult and my brain has developed differently, I donâ€™t feel that way anymore. Instead of the realities of adulthood crushing my spirit, it must be because the PokÃ©mon games donâ€™t have Professor Oak and Misty in them all the time.

If all youâ€™re looking at is video game sales numbers, you probably could foolishly think PokÃ©mon is â€œstrugglingâ€ in the market compared to what it hit in the â€˜90s, despite the absolute trashfire that was Scarlet and Violet still readily selling around 27 million copies, a number any other company would kill to hit. But PokÃ©mon is a lifestyle brand that makes most of its money from merchandise sales, and you would think someone who played a major role in inflating the value of the trading cards would know that.

Honestly, if people like Paul want something that feels just like the old games did when they were five, try a ROM hack. Fans have been making retro-style PokÃ©mon games for decades. Theyâ€™re not only great, theyâ€™ll probably also make you feel cozy-wozy with their pixelated graphics that look like what you played on your Game Boy. And hey, you can probably find plenty that donâ€™t include all the hundreds of new PokÃ©mon you donâ€™t like, but which millions of younger players grew up on and hold as dear as old-timers do Pikachu or Charmander.

This yearning for the mines of Kanto exists around the periphery of PokÃ©mon every day, and itâ€™s only going to ratchet up more this year with the seriesâ€™ 30th anniversary celebrations already paying tribute to those old games. ROM hacks, mock-ups from people who donâ€™t even like the games anymore, and even fan art are constantly gesturing at the seriesâ€™ old aesthetics. I still have my original copy of PokÃ©mon Yellow sitting on my shelf to this day, and maybe if Game Freak releases those old games on Switch this year, Iâ€™ll play it again. 

But I donâ€™t need The PokÃ©mon Company to keep looking back. And the company certainly doesnâ€™t need to tap into a â€œmassive,â€ untapped well of fair-weather fans who will come back to the franchise for good if they remake Red and Blue again. I think itâ€™ll live.

item.title: Roblox Player Performs Speedrunning Forensics To Uncover Fraud And Win Back World Record
item.content:encoded:
A player who goes by Quinten was on their way to securing a Guinness World Record in Roblox when they were beat out at the last moment by multiple speedruns that were so good, they seemed humanly impossible. A lesser player might have gone back to gambling on the Roblox ponies, but Quinten instead set out to prove that the new records were bogus. It worked.

As PCGamesN reports, Quinten was competing for the world record in a Roblox game called Ultimate Easy Obby that has over 100,000 reviews. Itâ€™s a zany, single-player obstacle course similar to something you might find in Fall Guys and was published by Roblox in partnership with the Guinness World Record company. Last month, Quinten secured a time of 05:48:96 following an â€œinsane back-and-forth battleâ€ with another Roblox speedrunner. It was the result of tons of time spent â€œoptimizing every corner and jump,â€ the 18-year-old Belgian wrote on Reddit.

But then something bizarre happened. Quintenâ€™s speedrun record was quickly beaten by three other random Roblox accounts. And not just by a little bit but six whole seconds. â€œFor context: a 6-second gap on a speedrun this optimized is physically impossible,â€ they wrote. â€œIt was heartbreaking to see a week of grinding ruined by scripts.â€ Undeterred, Quinten decided to speedrun an investigation into the mysterious rivals to find proof of the suspected cheating.

This evidence fell into three main buckets. The first was bogus time stamps. Ultimate Easy Obby features a linear obstacle course consisting of 50 stages, but some of the mystery accountsâ€™ timestamps were out of order. The new world record holder was also missing a â€œdigital receiptâ€ of ever having actually completed the race. â€œThis proved he never actually touched the finish line trigger; he likely teleported a coordinate script to the end-game lobby, bypassing the verification check,â€ Quinten wrote.

But the real nail in the coffin was painstaking frame-by-frame analysis of Quintenâ€™s own best recorded time to show that shaving six seconds off it would be impossible. â€œI took my best run and calculated the theoretical maximum time save possible (perfect pixels, zero drag),â€ they wrote. â€œEven with a TAS (Tool-Assisted Speedrun) level of perfection, the times the cheaters posted were mathematically impossible within the gameâ€™s physics engine.â€

Surprisingly, it all worked. The evidence was submitted to Guinness which then went back, reviewed the records, and re-validated Quintenâ€™s as the true World Record. â€œIt felt amazing to successfully lobby a major organization to reverse verified records based on user-submitted digital forensics,â€ they wrote. The king of Ultimate Easy Obby can once again rest easy knowing at least one more small sliver of fraud has been carved out of Roblox.
